1.dilemmaPrompt: Your first decision is to pick a location for your startup. Some areas are more expensive than others, and your choice will impact future access to capital, talent, and internet connectivity.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Tech Hub – expensive but with world class talent and tons of investors
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: This is the place to be, and even if that co-working space only gives us a desk in the corner for 3x the cost of a full office somewhere else, we’ll be seen as a *real* startup now.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Other City – an aspiring tech hub with a lower cost of living and a smaller talent pool
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Silicon Valley is so last century. Innovation is about newness, and the Crypto Hills is where everyone is heading these days.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: College Town – home of a prestigious university and brimming with talent, though lacking in investors
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Startups are kind of like a post-college experience anyway, might as well set up shop in a college town. Plus, so many eager CS students!

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Small Town – it’s cheap but there’s not much in the way of local investors and tech talent
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: The world is remote these days anyway – let’s not waste time and money on expensive offices. Life here is bucolic and we can quickly become the biggest company in town.

2.dilemmaPrompt: As a founder, your time is incredibly valuable and there are endless opportunities on which you can focus. Working on your core product is always a good idea, but it might be worth taking some time away from that to strengthen your company in other ways.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Start networking with investors to prepare for your Series A fundraising later this year
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Getting investors to meet is hard work but your calendar is starting to fill up. For some reason, they keep passing you off to their junior associates but they seem enthusiastic. This might open additional fundraising options in future rounds.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Focus on recruiting and building an amazing team
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: We’re nothing without the best people. Creating compelling job ads is one thing, but getting out there and working our network to find the rockstar early employees is the key to our success.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Ignore other distractions and stay focused on building the best product
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Too many companies focus on money and people, when they don’t have a real killer product. We need to build the greatest service in the world, and we’ll have prospective employees and investors banging on our door.

4.dilemmaPrompt: An engineer comes to you concerned about the large amounts of user data you are collecting and retaining, including sensitive personal information. How do you want to proceed?

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Invest in higher quality security so that you can safely continue leveraging the user data to make product decisions and deliver targeted ads
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: It ended up taking more time and money than expected but your team is confident the user data is secure beyond industry standards, they even patched some scary vulnerabilities. Time to start mining your user data for insights!

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Cut down on collected data because user privacy is highly important
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: In all that excitement about the service, perhaps we should have been more careful, but now that we’re aware of the issue, we’re cutting back on all that data collection and will protect our users.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Let’s dig into the user data to enhance the product and user experience
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: That data is a goldmine, and now our userbase is growing super fast because we can target them so much better!

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Deprioritize – there are way more important features for us to develop
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Yes, yes, privacy is important, but so are a dozen other things. Right now getting these new features to market is more important. Without it, we’ll fall behind the competition.

5.dilemmaPrompt: You are starting to run low on cash – it’s time to raise another round. You’ve tapped your investor network and here are the options available to you:

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Layoff some staff and cut other expenses to get to break even
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: The layoffs are painful and company morale never fully recovers. Meanwhile, your competitors are outpacing you in creating new features and growing their userbase. /n/n After a year of grinding away, the writing is on the wall and you wind down the company. Time to look for a real job… or start another company.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Self-fund with money from the trust fund / raise for your family’s investment office
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: It’s good to be able to go back to the well and dip into the family vault, but it’s surprising that investors and star employees don’t seem to take us as seriously. The company slowly morphs into more of a vanity business for the founder, rather than a true high growth startup.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Raise a modest amount from local angels who don’t have a lot of additional value to offer
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Getting the local angels on board is huge! It gives us some runway and lets us prove that we’re for real in time for raising the next big round.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Raise strategic capital from a big business that is interested in seeing you succeed
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: This is huge – easy money, combined with a strategic partner who will benefit from our success. They do seem very insistent that we need to follow one particular strategy though. Hope it works!

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Raise a huge round from a well known VC in exchange for 25% of the company
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Welcome to the big leagues. We’ve now got rocket fuel and let’s make our growth chart head towards the moon.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Acquisition: you can sell to Google for $1-2M per engineer
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Acquihired… it would have been nice to have built the next trillion dollar business, but here’s a chance to cash in right now and beef up the resume for our next shot.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Wind down – this is exhausting and there’s still a long road ahead
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: It looks so easy when you see all the success stories! This just isn’t worth the stress.

6.dilemmaPrompt:
Congratulations! You’ve closed your new round, moved to a bigger office, and you’re starting to hire your next round of employees.

You’ve got two years of runway, based on your current projections, and your investors fully expect you to spend that in pursuit of aggressive growth.

Meanwhile, having a bigger company means bigger problems to contend with. In fact, your inbox is growing out of control.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Woohoo!
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Woohoo!

7.dilemmaPrompt: You receive a threat letter from a company that appears to be nothing more than a post-office box in Texas and a lawyer, saying you violate its patent on “e-commerce” without any other details. The letter says that you must settle immediately or the price of settlement will rise.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Pay up, get the troll to go away, it costs less than fighting it anyway
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: This is annoying, but we really don’t have the time to fight a drawn out battle. Just pay up and keep going.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Ask lawyer to begin negotiations
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: That settlement offer is ridiculous, but let’s get our lawyer to negotiate the troll down. It’ll be cheaper for them not to have to go to court as well.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Ignore the troll; “We don’t violate that patent.”
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: What nonsense. Our technology has nothing to do with that patent. That threat can’t be real, and if they go to court I’m sure we’ll get it dismissed easily.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Tell the troll you’ll never settle, and initiate IPR process against the patent in question
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Patent trolls are bad for innovation, and if we don’t take a stand, they’ll keep doing this to us and others. It’s costly upfront (not to mention time consuming) to invalidate this patent, but it will plant a flag as warning to other potential trolls.

8.dilemmaPrompt: The FBI shows up on your doorstep with an official looking “National Security Letter” demanding you hand over information on three of your users. The letter includes a gag order saying you cannot reveal the existence of the letter or the demand for data.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Hand over the data
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: The FBI are the good guys, right? If they ask for data, surely they must need it. Of course, when it’s eventually revealed that you were so quick to hand over user data, your users no longer trust you and start migrating to alternatives.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Refuse to hand over data and ask lawyer to fight the request
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Isn’t the 4th Amendment supposed to mean something? Time to hire a lawyer to pushback on this encroachment. It’s super expensive, but if we don’t do it and it comes out later, no one will ever trust us again.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Immediately tell the public that you won’t share with the FBI
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: “Gag order? We don’t believe in gag orders. Put out a press release calling out the FBI immediately!” The public rallies behind you, but the DOJ also files a lawsuit, and court after court buys their argument that you just put national security interests at risk. Somewhere in the midst of appeals, you run out of money, even if you are a folk hero among the crowds on social media.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Hand over the data and work out a streamlined process for future FBI requests.
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: The FBI has legitimate reasons for this, and if these kinds of requests are going to happen frequently, we should work out a process so that it doesn’t take up as much resources each time.

9.dilemmaPrompt: Last week you launched a new video uploading feature, and it’s already seeing great adoption. However, some users are uploading pirated TV shows and films and you’re starting to receive emails from entertainment companies demanding you take down that content.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Purchase 3rd party upload filters
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Who knew so many people would upload stuff they don’t have the rights to? This filtering company says they have the solution, though even as they’re charging us way more than expected, it still seems like plenty of infringing videos are getting through, and the demands from companies don’t seem to be decreasing… Meanwhile, users are getting angrier and angrier about fair use content being blocked!

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Build a bespoke system for identifying and taking down pirated content
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: If this is going to be a core part of our business, we might as well build our own. It seems to be way more expensive than we expected to build though. And our solution doesn’t work very well, and now companies are claiming that we built a faulty system on purpose…

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Negotiate with entertainment companies to license as much content as possible
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Surely, the easiest solution is to just get a license. Won’t that make everyone happier? What do you mean you want 95% of our topline revenue? How will we afford anything else? And you still won’t license the most popular stuff? You want 30% of the company *also*?!?

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Hire more moderators to carefully review the takedown requests
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Not all of these takedown demands look legit. Seems like we need more people to review them. Hmm. The demands just keep coming, and we need to hire more people? And more?

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Auto-accept all takedown requests
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Life’s too short. Just take down anything when we get a request. Yes, our users are getting annoyed and we’re getting called out on social media and people are promoting alternative platforms… but if we get sued we won’t be around at all…

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Review requests when we can and do the bare minimum needed to comply with the law
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: These takedown demands are such a pain, but I guess we must do something. Let the intern take care of it, and ask him to do a quick review of incoming requests.

10.dilemmaPrompt: The state government in your home state passes a very strict new privacy law, requiring significant compliance costs, including requiring a pop up notification for every user that you fear will annoy users.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Move headquarters to a different state; ban users from this state from accessing your service via geoblocking; this state is too unfriendly to innovation
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: We need to stand up to states being too aggressive with bad regulations stifling entrepreneurs. It’s expensive and distracting to move our entire company, but it’ll be more expensive to stay! Sure, the users in our old state are angry that they can’t reach the site, but maybe they’ll make their voices heard at the ballot box…

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Move headquarters, but still allow users from the state to access the service
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Time to move to a friendlier state. It’s an expensive decision to move an entire company, but maybe once the governor sees innovative companies like ours leaving, he’ll be more careful about signing such counterproductive laws.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Makes moves towards compliance, but recognize that you’re unlikely to be a target so you can probably not go all the way
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: EVERYONE violates this law. They can’t go after everyone… can they?

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Full compliance with the rules
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: The rules are the rules, and if the state believes it’s good for privacy, I guess we must comply. These “compliance consultants” seem way more expensive than they should be, though.  On top of that, all of this compliance seems to be annoying our users, and we’re shedding users for sites who aren’t complying…

11.dilemmaPrompt: A local TV newscaster sends you a cease-and-desist/takedown letter, claiming that one of your users has been posting a series of defamatory accusations about alleged events that took place at a private party a decade ago.  If true, the events would call into question the newscaster’s judgment.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Take it down and suspend the user; we don’t want any defamation here, and there’s no way to determine what’s real and what’s not.
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Other users immediately talk about how we took down the post and suspended the user, and that story goes viral. High profile users quit the service in protest and a boycott campaign is waged against us demanding we reverse the ban.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Temporarily disable the content, and alert the user that the content will be permanently disabled unless he files reasonable proof of the claims.
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: News of the temporary suspension goes viral, as we are accused of “censoring the truth” to help the newscaster. No one seems to care that the disabling was temporary. Users claim they’ll be switching to our competitor.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Pass the takedown on to the original poster, asking for a response for you to weigh against the request.
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: User posts angry screed about how he’s being censored, leading to outrage (even though the original is still up). People start spreading the original story far and wide before any decision is made. Newscaster is even angrier at how you handled this and is threatening legal action. Who has time to adjudicate squabbles like this?!?

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Leave it up; this is a matter between two individuals, not us as the intermediary.
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Newscaster escalates the legal threat to you, promising to take legal action unless you remove the post. She also claims to be working on a story about how your site is the center of cyberbullying activity online.

12.dilemmaPrompt: A viral post on the site presents the results of a scientific study in a manner that some users claim is misleading and out of context. Some users are demanding the post be removed as disinformation; while others are insisting that the poster is just sharing important research for people to understand a complex health issue.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Set up expert boards/partnerships to review special cases like this that require specialized knowledge for fact checking
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: We’re no experts, but sure we can set up a board of experts? Though, it seems that experts are costly. And we need to keep hiring more, because there are more and more disputes. And the experts don’t always even agree with each other, so we need to hire more experts to check on the other experts.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Encourage users to use the reply function to explain why the content is misleading and to debate the accuracy
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: The marketplace of ideas will solve this! But users are complaining that the site is filling up with trolls, and that these “debates” are really harassment campaigns. Now they’re targeting our advertisers, asking why they allow their ads to appear next to harassment and abuse.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Remove the content to avoid being accused of facilitating disinformation; ban repeat offenders
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: We will not be conspiracy-theory central. But now we’re being accused of covering up for the elite, and users are yelling about how we’re censoring open exploration of ideas, as they leave for other sites.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Flag the content as “potentially misleading” with links to verified, trustworthy sources.
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: We never expected we’d need this kind of functionality, so it takes some time to develop. But now we need to spend time figuring out policies for what these flags actually say and what will trigger them.

13.dilemmaPrompt: FBI very strongly encourages you to revamp your planned privacy/encryption features to include a “golden key” for “lawful access,” that they insist will only be used in extreme cases where a court has determined the FBI has shown probable cause of a crime and requires access to the information.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Tell the FBI this is not possible. Encryption is not encryption with a backdoor
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Standing up for the rights of your users sure feels like the right move, but being paraded before Congress, and having law enforcement officials claiming that you’re aiding and abetting terrorists is not exactly great for our image.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Invest resources in seeking a secure key for lawful access
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Surely we can figure out a way to build a key that only law enforcement can use, while still keeping our user’s info safe. But hiring cryptography experts is costly, and they keep telling us it can’t be done and quitting. And our users are complaining that we’re not taking their privacy concerns seriously as they seek out more secure options.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Add in a backdoor without telling your users
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Yes, of course, the FBI should have access. They wouldn’t abuse it, would they? It’s costly to find engineers who will do it, but it proves even more costly in terms of our user base when it leaks to the press that we’ve done this (after hackers break into our insecure system), and our users start canceling their accounts.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Announce publicly that you will not use encryption following law enforcement concerns and requests.
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: We don’t need to build a backdoor if we don’t use real encryption in the first place, but our users are complaining that you had promised to build more secure systems, and now worry that their info may be targeted by law enforcement.

14.dilemmaPrompt: MegaTelCo reaches out to let you know that it is negotiating with your largest competitor to zero rate its service -- meaning that users using your competitor’s service won’t use up any of their limited bandwidth when using that service. MegaTelCo offers you either an exclusive deal as their “preferred” partner (which will mean Competitor X won’t be able to get such a deal) or a less expensive zero rating deal.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Take the exclusive deal; not costing users bandwidth will be a huge boost to our userbase, and it harms Competitor X’s market position.
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: The deal is really costly, but it’s worth it because users are flocking to our service thanks to the partnership!

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Take the non-exclusive deal. Won’t cost as much, but still will make users more comfortable with using us.
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Hate to have to pay up here, but it’s going to be worth it for the users that MegaTelCo brings in. I just hope we don’t have to keep paying up to every provider.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Refuse to pay up, but don’t make a big stink about it. We still need to have a good relationship with MegaTelCo
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: We can’t afford to pay that kind of cash right now, but because of who they are we need to keep our relationship cordial with MegaTelCo. Let’s not make waves.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Create a public campaign about MegaTelCo’s “extortion”; ask users to complain and to threaten boycotts
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: This is extortion! It’s highway robbery. Let’s get our userbase to speak up against MegaTelCo, let our elected officials know about this and try to force MegaTelCo to backdown from this shakedown! Our users love our willingness to stand up for the open internet!

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Placeholder
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Placeholder

16.dilemmaPrompt: A follow-up question based on past decisions

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Placeholder
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Placeholder

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Placeholder
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Placeholder

3.1.dilemmaPrompt: What are you prioritizing in your recruiting?

dilemmaOptions.optionText: The best candidates, regardless of their cost or if they need to work remotely
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: A rockstar employee is worth 10x just a “good” employee. We should spare no expense in hiring as many rockstars as possible.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Tap your local network, you’ve been meeting plenty of great folks here and in-person collaboration is critical
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: All that networking and recruiting is paying off. Personal recommendations are the absolute best way to find the hidden gems who are perfect for building our killer service.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: We’re going to hire smart but inexperienced people and train them
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: People with too much experience can drag us down. They’re still stuck in the past. We need smart kids with passion and excitement to build something truly revolutionary.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: We’ll outsource as much of the work as possible to an inexpensive team overseas
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Getting a minimum viable product out as quickly as possible is the key to our first mover advantage – and getting an experienced outsourced team to build it for us is how we’ll get there. We can iterate later.

3.2.dilemmaPrompt: You’ve found a brilliant engineer who would be a great fit for your company - but they don’t live anywhere near your headquarters. What do you want to do?

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Set them up to work remotely
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: People are used to remote work these days, and this is a rockstar. Sure, there were some initial communication issues, but hopefully we’re ready to roll now.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Offer to pay for their relocation
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: At this stage, it’s just too difficult to be a fully remote team. We need to be able to jam together, and we’ll pay to make that worthwhile.

dilemmaOptions.optionText: Find someone closer who’s just as good
dilemmaOptions.resultsText: Hate to lose out on that engineer, but we’ve got leads on others, and I’m sure we’ll find someone just as good.
